name: Payment Precedes Verification
definition: Money flows to the provider, plan, or beneficiary before an independent party confirms that the billed service was delivered, was medically necessary, or that the beneficiary was eligible.
recognition_test: 1. Is payment issued before an independent party (not the billing entity) confirms the service was actually delivered? 2. Is there a time gap of more than 7 days between payment and any verification activity? 3. Is the government's primary recourse retrospective (audits, overpayment demands) rather than prospective (prior authorization, real-time adjudication)? If YES to any, this quality is likely present.
exploitation_logic: When payment precedes verification, the cost of fraud is borne entirely by the payer's recovery apparatus. Bad actors can submit claims, receive payment, and dissipate funds before any audit occurs. The retrospective recovery process is slow, expensive, and recovers only a fraction of losses. This fundamentally shifts the economics in favor of fraudulent billing — the expected value of fraud is positive because the probability of recovery is low and the delay is long.
canonical_examples: Medicare FFS processes 1B+ claims annually and pays first, then audits — enabling Operation Gold Rush's $10.6B in DME claims
ACA advance premium tax credits paid monthly before IRS reconciliation, which was paused 2021-2024

name: Self-Attesting Payment Basis
definition: The entity that receives payment is also the entity that generates or controls the data that determines the payment amount, with no independent third-party verification of that data.
recognition_test: 1. Does the entity receiving payment generate the key data input (diagnosis codes, service logs, eligibility determinations) that directly determines how much it gets paid? 2. Is there an independent party that validates this data BEFORE it affects payment? 3. Could the paying entity detect data manipulation without conducting a clinical audit? If the answer to #1 is YES and #2 is NO, this quality is present.
exploitation_logic: Self-attestation creates an information asymmetry where the billing entity has both the incentive and the ability to manipulate the data that determines its payment. Unlike arms-length transactions where a buyer can inspect goods before paying, the payer here relies entirely on the seller's self-reported data. The only check is retrospective audit, which samples a tiny fraction of claims. This makes systematic data manipulation (upcoding, false diagnosis reporting, inflated hours) nearly undetectable at scale.
canonical_examples: MA plans report their own diagnosis codes that determine their own risk-adjusted payment — Kaiser added 500K false diagnoses
Hospice providers certify the terminal prognosis that triggers their own per diem payment
ACA applicants self-attest income that determines their own subsidy amount — GAO found 100% of fictitious applications approved

name: Uncapped New Payment Category
definition: A new billing code, product category, or reimbursement pathway exists without concurrent volume limits, prior authorization requirements, or spending caps, and has not yet developed a baseline of expected utilization against which anomalies can be measured.
recognition_test: 1. Was this billing code or payment category created or significantly expanded within the last 5 years? 2. Is there NO prior authorization requirement for services in this category? 3. Is there NO annual or per-beneficiary spending cap? 4. Does CMS or the relevant payer lack a historical baseline of 'normal' utilization for this category? If YES to #1 AND any of #2-4, this quality is present.
exploitation_logic: New payment categories are the frontier of fraud because they combine high per-unit reimbursement (designed to incentivize adoption) with low oversight (controls haven't been built yet) and no anomaly baseline (there's no 'normal' to compare against). Word spreads through the fraud ecosystem when a new high-margin, low-scrutiny billing opportunity is discovered. The absence of prior authorization means that volume is constrained only by claims processing capacity, not clinical review.
canonical_examples: Part B skin substitute codes went from $256M to $10B in 5 years with no prior auth
COVID telehealth codes with new modifiers and relaxed place-of-service requirements
Done Global exploited newly flexible Schedule II telehealth prescribing rules

name: Subjective Clinical Criteria
definition: The eligibility determination or medical necessity judgment that triggers payment depends on clinical opinion or patient self-report that is inherently difficult to independently verify, rather than on objective, measurable criteria.
recognition_test: 1. Does the payment-triggering determination rely on clinical judgment rather than objective lab values, imaging, or measurable criteria? 2. Could two qualified clinicians reasonably reach opposite conclusions on the same patient? 3. Is patient self-report a primary input to the determination? If YES to #1 AND either #2 or #3, this quality is present.
exploitation_logic: Subjective criteria make it nearly impossible to prove a claim is fraudulent without a clinician reviewing the specific case — and even then, legitimate clinical disagreement provides cover. This dramatically increases the cost of fraud detection (requires expert clinical review per case) while reducing the probability of successful prosecution (defendants can argue clinical judgment). Bad actors exploit this by systematically resolving every subjective judgment in the direction that maximizes payment.
canonical_examples: Hospice terminal prognosis (6-month life expectancy) is a clinical judgment call
ADHD diagnosis in Done Global's telehealth model based on brief screen and self-report
Behavioral health diagnoses in Arizona Medicaid fraud relied on patient self-report and clinical interpretation

name: Payment Disconnected from Delivery
definition: The payment structure is flat, bundled, or capitated in a way that creates no marginal cost to the provider for reducing service quantity or intensity below what was paid for.
recognition_test: 1. Is the payment amount the same regardless of how many services are actually delivered within the payment period? 2. Does the provider retain more revenue by delivering fewer or less intensive services? 3. Is there no minimum service delivery threshold as a condition of payment? If YES to #1 AND #2, this quality is present.
exploitation_logic: When payment is disconnected from delivery, the profit-maximizing strategy is to minimize costs while collecting full payment. In per diem models (hospice), this means enrolling patients and providing minimal services. In capitated models (MA, PACE), this means enrolling healthier-than-average patients or under-serving enrolled patients. The less you do, the more you keep. This is the inverse of FFS over-service fraud — equally harmful but harder to detect because the absence of service leaves less data trail than the presence of false claims.
canonical_examples: Hospice per diem pays the same daily rate whether the patient receives full IDT visits or nothing
MA capitation pays per member per month regardless of service volume — incentivizing under-service while coding for maximum risk adjustment

name: Expansion Outpaces Oversight
definition: A major policy change has dramatically expanded enrollment, provider participation, or covered services faster than the responsible oversight body has built corresponding monitoring, credentialing, or audit capacity.
recognition_test: 1. Has the program's enrollment, spending, or provider count grown by more than 50% in the last 3-5 years? 2. Has the oversight body's staffing, audit capacity, or monitoring infrastructure grown proportionally? 3. Were recent waivers or emergency flexibilities granted that relaxed normal enrollment screening or oversight requirements? If YES to #1 and NO to #2, or YES to #3, this quality is present.
exploitation_logic: Rapid expansion creates a window of vulnerability where the ratio of transactions-to-oversight-capacity spikes. Fraud actors are highly attuned to these windows because they represent a period of maximum impunity. Emergency waivers and flexibilities compound this by lowering the barriers to entry that normally screen out bad actors. The oversight deficit may persist long after the expansion because building institutional audit capacity takes years while expanding a billing program takes months.
canonical_examples: COVID telehealth waivers relaxed provider enrollment screening while expanding who could bill
ACA enhanced subsidies drove 60%+ enrollment growth but CMS fraud risk assessment unchanged since 2018
Arizona behavioral health spending grew 5x in 2 years; state oversight was not proportional

name: Intermediary Opacity
definition: Financial flows pass through one or more intermediary entities that obscure the economic relationship between the government payment and the ultimate recipient or service, making it difficult to determine whether payments reflect value or constitute disguised kickbacks or profit extraction.
recognition_test: 1. Do payments pass through intermediary entities (PBMs, brokers, foundations, management companies, TPAs) between the government payer and the entity delivering the service? 2. Are the financial terms of these intermediary arrangements opaque to the government payer? 3. Could the intermediary structure be used to disguise payments that would otherwise violate the Anti-Kickback Statute? If YES to #1 AND either #2 or #3, this quality is present.
exploitation_logic: Intermediaries create opacity that enables two categories of abuse: (1) disguised kickbacks, where payments that would be illegal if made directly are laundered through an intermediary (copay foundations, management companies), and (2) spread extraction, where the intermediary captures the difference between what it charges the payer and what it pays the provider, with no transparency about the magnitude or justification of the spread. The more intermediary layers, the harder it is to follow the money.
canonical_examples: Teva used nominally independent copay foundations to funnel kickbacks ($450M settlement)
PBM spread pricing — CVS Caremark found liable for $290M in inflated Part D prices
ACA broker system enabled unauthorized batch enrollments for commission capture

name: Low Barriers to Billing Entry
definition: The credentialing, enrollment, or licensing requirements to become an entity that can bill a federal health program are low enough that bad actors can rapidly establish or acquire billing entities, sometimes dozens at once.
recognition_test: 1. Can a new entity begin billing within 90 days of application? 2. Are there no experience, education, or capitalization requirements for the entity's principal operators? 3. Can billing privileges be effectively transferred by acquiring an existing entity? 4. Is there no site visit or in-person verification before billing begins? If YES to two or more, this quality is present.
exploitation_logic: Low barriers enable two attack patterns: (1) rapid proliferation, where a single criminal organization establishes many billing entities simultaneously to maximize claim volume before detection, and (2) entity acquisition, where bad actors purchase existing enrolled entities to inherit their billing privileges and avoid the scrutiny applied to new enrollees. Both patterns exploit the fact that initial enrollment screening is the primary filter — once past it, the entity has access to the payment system.
canonical_examples: Operation Gold Rush purchased dozens of legitimate DME companies to inherit their billing privileges
Hospice fraud enabled by lack of administrator certification requirements
Sham behavioral health treatment facilities in Arizona required minimal state licensing
